runs.text: Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that there are leaders in many places. This story is about voting for leaders in government.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
What is something you will need to
today? Tell your partner about it.
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word in the title that describes something that is very big. (huge)
when voting? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Mom says the laws should be fair for everyone. Do you agree? Why or why not?
When have you voted for someone or something?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that there are three branches in the United States government, and each branch plays a different role.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
of something is a part or section of it.
Baseball and basketball are part of the sports
of the food store would you find milk?
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that means the same as together. (union)
What happens to a bill after the legislative branch agrees on it? Find the sentences that answer the question.
of the government makes sure the laws are being followed?
What is a law the government has passed that you think is important? Why is it important?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up tothe next days lesson.
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students circle words with long
. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss the different end punctuation for sentences 1 (period), 2 (exclamation point), and 3 (question mark).
Model how you change your intonation when reading a question (raise voice at end) or exclamation (read with excitement).
Have students echo-read the sentences, replicating your intonation. Repeat for sentences 4, 5, and 6.
Read the title. Explain that this text is in the form of a cartoon. The speech bubbles show what each character is saying to the other.
For the first reading, have one partner read Dads words and the other read the daughters words. Then have partners switch roles and reread the words.
Prompt students to find all the words with long
spellings in the speech bubbles. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student Observation Form.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to the word.
Explain that students will read about what it means to vote in this country.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means to stand in place for something.
How can you use a gesture to
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question:
Find the word that tells what leaders do with old laws if they want to change them. (review)
them on Election Day? Find sentences that answer this question.
Some words have more than one meaning. The word
can mean correct, a privilege, or the opposite of left. What does
mean in the last sentence of the first paragraph on page 18?
How have elected leaders helped your community? Tell about it.
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students circle words with long
spellings. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have them read the sentence to a partner.
Identify and contrast the different words used to begin questions 1 (Did), 2 (Can), 4 (Do), 6 (What), 7 (Which).
Model how to build a question with one of the question words:
Did you see that car go by?
Have students build their own questions using some of the question words.

Read the title. Explain that this shows how the three branches, or parts, of the government are connected. This text includes a diagram and a list. Authors include diagrams to help readers understand the parts of something important to remember. They include lists to make it easier to remember related information.
Guide students through a reading of the selection, including the diagram.
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the diagram.

Read the title and have students repeat as they point to each word. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the e-book for support before they read the book on their own.
Explain to students that they will read a text about different rules and laws we follow.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means to make sure or make certain.
that I will get a seat at the show.
you will do well on a test?
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that tells who works together in school. (pupils)
What should you do when you want to speak in school? Find the sentence that answers the question.
that people will stay safe? How do they
What are some rules you follow in your school?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this text is an interview with a candidate running for class president. Ask students what they would ask this candidate.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
is a reason or intention for something.
of a heavy coat is to keep you warm.
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Which word tells about how many questions Mike wants to ask Lulu? (few)
What does Lulu want to do about lunch? Find the sentence that answers the question.
How would you describe Lulu? Why?
If you were class president, what would you try to do for your class? Why?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
